awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Bulldog Connectivity and Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The Bulldog Connectivity and Research Network  (BCR net) project at South Carolina State University (SCSU) creates a network infrastructure to accommodate increasing research activities in STEM and non-traditional areas such as the library, visual arts, museum and the planetarium. The campus enterprise network, plagued with bandwidth bottlenecks, supports only administrative, and academic needs, which competes for simultaneous use of limited resources. Disparate silos of unconnected computing resources have supported research computing in research labs with little scalability to the evolution of research needs. The BCR net provides a frictionless redundant design dedicated to research computing that delivers high-speed connectivity. Its design focuses on isolating high-throughput research functions through data paths on operationally efficient high-speed connections to research partners.

BCR net, separate from the campus enterprise network, gives SCSU researchers access to on-demand high bandwidth science DMZ connections to sharable storage of research data connected to high throughput data transfer nodes with secure digital connections. Transfers of large datasets and instructions will be enabled under projects such as the Robotically Controlled Telescope Consortium, the NSF Partnership in Observational and Computational Astronomy (POCA), the NSF SCI-STEPS INCLUDES Project. Other areas affected include; the Physics and Chemistry computational labs for astrophysics and cancer research, the digital media lab, the historical collection and archiving Orangeburg massacre collection, applied radiation sciences lab, the Nuclear Engineering program reactor simulation lab, and the computer science security lab.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project established a separate dedicated research network with increased capacity and functionality to support multidisciplinary research programs at the campus of South Carolina State University. This network provides a secure digital workplace with high bandwidth internet access for researchers to  compute, store, and share research data. This scalable network can be used for further network enhancements to meet the growing needs of collaborative and multi-disciplinary data-driven research and science education at SC State University.

This dedicated research centric network is designed to deliver high-speed connectivity (10 Gbps of capacity) among research organization Data Transfer Nodes (DTNs), Internet2, storage nodes, and multiple laboratories serving computer science, physics, science, and engineering programs. This infrastructure upgrade helps SCSU to move forward toward vertical integration with regional networks by replacing the current border router with a new, high-speed capable aggregate service router, changing the data center design from a three-tier to spine leaf architecture to remove bottlenecks and by applying a software-defined networking Science DMZs.

 

This planned integration to national networks will reinforce the growing undergraduate research activities (planned and on-going) with partners such as Clemson University, Western Kentucky University, Villanova University, Vanderbilt University, the Medical University of South Carolina, the National Radio Astronomy Observatory and the University of South Carolina. This will also help us with our on-going and planned research collaborations through the advancement of scientific and engineering knowledge in a variety of fields including astrophysics, cancer research, environmental science, medical science, nuclear engineering, physics and more.  This will help faculty and students to engage in high-throughput and high-resolution analysis, and network optimization and network security research, which currently are not available or impractical. By implementing remote experiment control features to lab equipment, this project will also help address the geographical challenge of campus access experienced by students living in outlying towns.

 

The specific goals and objectives of the CC* Networking Infrastructure: Bulldog Connectivity and Research was to establish the Bulldog Connectivity and Research Network (BCR net) capable of  delivering a dedicated and scalable data center and provide a secure digital workspace where researchers compute, store, and share research data on high bandwidth Internet access and on a variety of devices. The project has enabled these goals by upgrading key campus networking connections and implementing new tools for data movement. This project represents the next step in closing the STEM education gap that prevents rural communities from entering STEM professions, a national economic and security priority.
